mitre_attack_techniques.signature_description: An adversary may attempt to get detailed information about the operating system and hardware, including version, patches, hotfixes, service packs, and architecture.
Adversaries may communicate using application layer protocols to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic.
Adversaries may employ a known encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol.
Adversaries may inject code into processes in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges.
Adversaries may create or modify references in user document templates to conceal malicious code or force authentication attempts.
Potential document exploit detected (performs HTTP gets)
Potential document exploit detected (unknown TCP traffic)
Potential document exploit detected (performs DNS queries)
Creates files inside the user directory
Checks if Microsoft Office is installed
Uses HTTPS for network communication, use the SSL MITM Proxy cookbook for further analysis

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Office Application Initiated Network Connection To Non-Local IP
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an office application (Word, Excel, PowerPoint)  that initiate a network connection to a non-private IP addresses.
This rule aims to detect traffic similar to one seen exploited in CVE-2021-42292.
This rule will require an initial baseline and tuning that is specific to your organization.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE '@scythe_io', Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Tim Shelton, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

issuer.CN: Microsoft Azure RSA TLS Issuing CA 07
Microsoft Azure RSA TLS Issuing CA 07
Microsoft Azure RSA TLS Issuing CA 08
Microsoft Azure ECC TLS Issuing CA 03
Microsoft Azure RSA TLS Issuing CA 03
